resources.string: IBD patient empowerment application developed by\nSimon Knowles
What is your highest level of education completed?
How many months ago did you last see your gastroenterologist?
Number of years diagnosed with IBD?
In the past 3 months my IBD has been:
Over the past week, how many bowel movements have you had per day?
Over the past week, how many of your bowel movements have been loose/watery stools per day?
General well-being over the last week
Over the past week, my rectal bleeding has been:
Over the past week have you taken any antidiarrheal medication?
Have you experienced a fever over the past week?
Have you experienced an abdominal mass/tenderness over the last week?
Have you experienced abdominal pain or cramping over the last week?
Please tick any complications you are currently experiencing. (Please select as many as relevant)
If yes, how many months have you had a stoma?
If yes, what type of stoma do you have?
Have you been diagnosed with any of the following conditions along with IBD? (Please select as many as relevant)
Compared to your last visit to the gastroenterologist, how would you describe the status of your IBD SYMPTOMS now?
Compared to your last visit to the gastroenterologist, how would you describe the status of your PAIN now?
Compared to your last visit to the gastroenterologist, how would you describe any changes to the FREQUENCY OF BOWEL MOVEMENTS now?
Irritations and inflammation of the eye (e.g., Iritis/uveitis)
Inflammation of the skin (e.g., Erythema nodosum, Pyoderma gangrenosum)
No (if NO – no further questions skip next question).
Many more bowel movements each day
Less frequent bowel movements each day

string-array.name: condition
string-array.item: Crohn\'s disease with Irritable Bowel Syndrome
Ulcerative colitis with Irritable Bowel Syndrome

string-array.name: past_3_month_ibd
string-array.item: Constantly active, giving me symptoms every day
Often active, giving me symptoms most days
Sometimes active, giving me symptoms on some days (for instance 1–2 days / week)
Occasionally active, giving me symptoms 1–2 days / month
Rarely active, giving me symptoms on a few days in the past 3 months
I was well in the past 3 months, what I consider a remission or absence of symptoms

resources.string: What other medications are you taking?
The following set of questions ask about your medications you are currently taking.
Drug dosage and method of entry
What other medications are you taking?
Drug dosage and method of entry
What other medications are you taking?
I\'m not taking any medications for my IBD
I don\'t know what medications I\'m taking for my IBD

string-array.name: drug_array
string-array.item: I\'m not taking any medications for my IBD
I don\'t know what medications I\'m taking for my IBD
Prednisolone (also known as Solone, Predsone, Panafcort)
Mesalazine (also known as 5-aminosalicylic acid, 5-ASA, Pentasa, Mezavant, Salofalk, Colazide)
Azathioprine (also known as AZA, Imuran, Thioprine, Azapin, Azamun, Azahexal)
Allopurinol (also known as Zyloprim, Allohexal, Allosig, Progout)
Ciprofloxacin (also known as C-Flox, Ciloquin, Ciprol, Ciproxin, Ciloxan)

string-array.name: index_7
string-array.item: 750mg (3 x three times per day) oral

I only take my medications when my symptoms get worse

resources.string: Individuals tend to report minimal levels of psychological distress
For further information and strategies to manage psychological distress related to IBD please go to IBDclinic.org.au
If you have any questions or concerns please talk to your Gastroenterologist or IBD nurse
Individuals tend to report some symptoms which may be associated with psychological distress. These symptoms may be causing some distress in your life.

We recommend you meet with your mental health professional or doctor if symptoms worsen. For further information and strategies to manage psychological distress related to IBD please go to IBDclinic.org.au
If you have any questions or concerns please talk to your Gastroenterologist or IBD nurse
Individuals tend to report strong and frequent symptoms which may be associated with psychological distress
Unless you are doing so already, we recommend you contact your mental health professional or doctor as soon as possible to arrange a mental health review.
Please review these results with your Gastroenterologist or IBD nurse
Quality of life and social support
Mental health concerns are a common issue in patients living with IBD. This section will ask you about your mental health symptoms and provide feedback that may be of benefit.
Please indicate how you feel on average over the past week. (higher scores indicate more intense symptoms)
How you feel on average over the past week (DEPRESSION):
How you feel on average over the past week (ANXIETY):
How you feel on average over the past week (STRESS):
How you feel on average over the past week (FATIGUE):
Please move the red rectangle along the line to indicate your global level of quality of life (higher scores indicate greater quality of life)
Please indicate your global level of social support available to you (higher scores indicate greater levels of social support)
Please identify the average number of hours sleep in the last 24 hours:
Please indicate how you would rate the quality of sleep you attain in an average 24 hour period. (higher scores indicate greater quality of sleep)
Do you consider hurting yourself, others, or feel suicidal?
Are you currently are CURRENTLY seeing a mental health professional?
Do you have an appointment with a mental health expert within the next 14 days or willing to contact your local doctor (GP) if your mental health symptoms worsen?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel tired out for not good reason?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel nervous?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel so nervous that nothing could calm you
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel hopeless?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel restless or fidgety?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel so restless you could not sit still?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel depressed?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel that everything was an effort?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel so sad that nothing could cheer you up?
During the last 30 days, about often did you feel wprthless?

Mental health concerns are a common issue in patients living with IBD. Based on your responses, the program has calculated your levels of psychological distress.Please be aware that these results are only subjective. A comprehensive assessment by a trained mental health specialist is needed to confirm any diagnosis or symptom severity.If you have any concerns or questions, please talk to your IBD nurse, gastroenterologist, medical practitioner or mental health professional (e.g., psychiatrist, psychologist).
How likely are you to follow up on the advice that was provided?
Did you experience any distress after receiving feedback about your results?
Are the results provided consistent with your sense of current mental health status?
Have you made any changes to your diet because of your IBD?
If YES, who has guided this change?
If YES, which of the following diets are you following? You may select as many as apply.
If YES, do you feel that these changes have improved your gastrointestinal symptoms?
Have you lost weight as a result of your IBD?
Do you have any concerns in relation to your diet and IBD?
Overall, how healthy do you believe your diet is?
I have made changes based on my symptoms
Yes. Please specify how much over the 6 months (note: 1 kilogram = 2.2 pounds):
Please specify how much over the 6 months (note: 1 kilogram = 2.2 pounds)
Please rate your overall level of self–confidence when it comes to managing your own physical health?
Please rate your overall level of self–confidence when it comes to managing your own mental health?
Please rate your overall level of self–confidence when it comes to keeping physically fit?
Please rate your overall level of self–confidence when it comes to maintaining a healthy diet?
Please rate your overall level of self–confidence when it comes to taking your medication as recommended?
Please rate your overall level of self–confidence when it comes to quitting smoking
How do I get into remission? How long can I stay in remission?
Review of recent diagnostic tests (e.g., imaging, blood test, stool test)
General well–being (e.g. fatigue, energy levels, sleeping patterns)
In our session today, I would like to talk about: (please tick as many that are relevant)
How did you go completing this goal?
How did you go completing this goal?
How did you go completing this goal?
Since the last visit to the clinic, how did you go working towards your goals?
How did you go completing this goal?

string-array.name: array_modue_12_ga
string-array.item: I have NO goals I want to work on
Work on strategies to better manage my pain
Work on strategies to reduce stress in my life
Work on strategies to reduce psychological symptoms

string-array.name: m_12_index_2
string-array.item: Organise a meeting with doctor to discuss options
Read and try suggested methods from the pain management handout at IBDclinic.org.au
Search for information on pain management strategies and try them out
Start a daily to record when pain occurs and what factors influence it (e.g., stressors, food)
Try out a mindfulness based intervention

string-array.name: m_12_index_3
string-array.item: Search for information on stress management strategies and try them out
Engage in relaxation techniques (e.g., deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation) for at least 10 minutes each day
Write down concerns and identify practical ways to help reduce or resolve them
Take a relaxing bath at least once a week
Engage in light exercise 20 minutes a day
Engage in a rewarding activity (e.g., hobby) each day
Listen to uplifting music at least once a day
Watch a funny movie at least once a week
Reduce caffeine and sugar intake each day
Avoid alcohol, cigarettes, and other recreational drug
Each day look for opportunities for self–discovery

string-array.name: m_12_index_4
string-array.item: Organise a meeting with psychologist to discuss options
Organise a meeting with doctor to discuss options
Search for information on reducing psychological symptoms and try them out
Engage in relaxation techniques (e.g., deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation) for at least 10 minutes each day
Write down concerns and identify practical ways to help reduce or resolve them
Go for a daily walk (minimum of 15 minutes per day)
Take a relaxing bath at least once a week
Engage in light exercise 20 minutes a day
Engage in a rewarding activity (e.g., hobby) each day
Listen to uplifting music at least once a day
Watch a funny movie at least once a week
Reduce caffeine and sugar intake each day
Avoid alcohol, cigarettes, and other recreational drug
Each day look for opportunities for self–discovery

string-array.name: m_12_index_5
string-array.item: Search for information on becoming more physically fit and try them out
Talk with a fitness instructor and start a plan to engage in more exercise
Go to the gym at least once a week
Engage in at least one physical activity (minimum of 15 minutes per day) (e.g., walking)
Take the stairs instead of the lift at least once a day
Use a pedometer and increase your daily walking patterns by 10%
Use a pedometer and increase your daily walking patterns by 20%
Swim or do water aerobics at least once a week
Take a class in martial arts, dance, or yoga class once a week
Engage in a community sporting activity (e.g., football, cricket)

string-array.name: m_12_index_6
string-array.item: Organise a meeting with a dietician
Follow the diet recommended by my dietician
Reduce daily consumption of fatty foods from my diet
Reduce daily consumption of sugar/junk food from my diet
Increase daily consumption of breads and cereals

string-array.name: m_12_index_7
string-array.item: Increase water intake (1 cup per day)
Increase water intake (2 cup per day)
Increase water intake (3+ cup per day)
Reduce coffee/tea intake (no more than 1 per day)
Reduce coffee/tea intake (no more than 2 per day)
Reduce coffee/tea intake (no more than 3 per day)

string-array.name: m_12_index_8
string-array.item: Discuss ways to manage my medication with pharmacist
Purchase and use a Webster pack
Plan when to take medications and set a reminder using a watch alarm or smartphone application

string-array.name: m_12_index_9
string-array.item: Organise a meeting with gastroenterologist to discuss gastroenterologist–related medication options
Organise a meeting with doctor to discuss medication options
Organise a meeting with psychiatrist to discuss mental health–related medication options

string-array.name: m_12_index_10
string-array.item: Arrange a second option from another doctor/gastroenterologist

string-array.name: m_12_index_11
string-array.item: Find information about sleep hygiene techniques and try them
Set a regular time to go to bed
Engage in relaxation techniques (e.g., deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation) for at least 10 minutes to help get to sleep
Set a regular time to go to sleep
Use a worry diary to write down concerns, and then engage in relaxation for at least 10 minutes prior to going to bed
Nap to make up for lost sleep
Wake up at the same time every day
Make my bedroom a better sleep environment (e.g., no TV, keep dark, quiet, cool, and comfortable)

string-array.name: m_12_index_12
string-array.item: Organise a meeting with doctor to discuss medication options
Organise a meeting with psychologist to discuss hypnosis/habit reduction options
Start quit smoking program e.g., www.quitnow.gov.au
Delay smoking by a few minutes/hours
Reduce the number of cigarettes I have on me

string-array.name: m_12_index_13
string-array.item: Organise a meeting with doctor to discuss medication options
Organise a meeting with psychologist to discuss hypnosis/habit reduction options
Start alcohol reduction program e.g., http://www.alcohol.gov.au/
Delay drinking alcohol by a few minutes/hours

What would you like to print?

HOW DO THEY COMPARE TO THE LAST APPOINTMENT
iPEAPS developed by Simon Knowles - MindOverGut©

K10 score between 10–15 (Normal): Individuals tend to report minimal levels of psychological distress.\nK10 score between 16–30 (Mild–moderate distress): Individuals tend to report some symptoms which may be associated with psychological distress. These symptoms may be causing some distress in their life.\nK10 score between 31–50 (Severe distress): Individuals tend to report strong and frequent symptoms which may be associated with psychological distress.
